titleStmt.title: Adaptive Finite-Time Stabilization of Stochastic Nonlinear Systems Subject to Full-State Constraints and Input Saturation

analytic.title: Adaptive Finite-Time Stabilization of Stochastic Nonlinear Systems Subject to Full-State Constraints and Input Saturation

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: In this paper, the adaptive finite-time tracking control is studied for state constrained stochastic nonlinear systems with parametric uncertainties and input saturation. To this end, a definition of semi-globally finite-time stability in probability (SGFSP) is presented and a related stochastic Lyapunov theorem is established and proved. To alleviate the serious uncertainties and state constraints, the adaptive backstepping control and barrier Lyapunov function (BLF) are combined in a unified framework. Then, by applying a function approximation method and the auxiliary system method to deal with input saturation respectively, two adaptive state-feedback controllers are constructed. Based on the proposed stochastic Lyapunov theorem, each constructed controller can guarantee the closed-loop system achieves SGFSP, the system states remain in the defined compact sets and the output tracks the reference signal very well. Finally, a stochastic single-link robot system is established and used to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed schemes.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: As an important topic of control field, the stabilization problems of nonlinear systems have achieved abundant results; see, for instance [1]- [5] and numerous references therein. When practical nonlinear systems encounter stochastic noises or disturbances, they can be modeled by stochastic differential equations and called as stochastic nonlinear systems. The investigation and analysis of stochastic nonlinear systems are important to stabilize practical systems. In recent years, the basic Lyapunov stability theory [6], backstepping technique [7]- [8] and adaptive control [9] have motivated remarkable control results done on stochastic nonlinear systems in various structures; see [10]- [16] and the related references.

Note that constraints especially state constraints in the form of physical stoppage, performance and safety specifications widely occur in practical systems, which may lead to performance degradation, hazards and system damage. Hence, how to handle the constraints in controller design is an significant work. For this issue, barrier Lyapunov function (BLF) is an effective tool since it can yield a value that approaches infinity whenever its arguments approach some limits. In the past years, [17] and [18] with only output constraints by adopting BLF. Subsequently, with the help of BLF and backstepping technique, the control and design has been frequently studied in [19]- [21] for deterministic nonlinear systems with full-state constraints. But for stochastic nonlinear systems, there are very few results concerned with the constrained control problems. In [22] and [23], the fuzzy and neural network approximation approaches were combined with BLF and thus solved the tracking control for two classes of nonstrict-feedback nonlinear systems, but only output constraints were considered. For full-state constraints cases, [24] addressed the adaptive control problem of stochastic nonlinear systems for the first time by constructing BLF in symmetric and asymmetric forms. Based on neural network and BLF, the adaptive tracking control was further considered in [25] for stochastic nonlinear pure-feedback systems with full-state constraints and input saturation. It should be noticed that [22]- [25] only paid attention to the convergence of systems in infinite time.

On the other hand, input saturation that may degrade control performance and even destroy system stability, is also unavoidable in practical systems. During the past years, through using a smooth function to approximate input saturation (see, e.g., [25] and [26]- [28]) or introducing an auxiliary system to compensate input saturation ( [29]), different stabilization problems have been addressed for stochastic nonlinear systems. To the authors' knowledge, only [25] considered full-state constraints in stochastic nonlinear system control but it didn't investigate uncertain parameters. Hence, how to control state constrained stochastic nonlinear systems with both input saturation and parametric uncertainties is a motivation of this study.

Furthermore, it is rather meaningful to ensure the systems to converge in finite time for stochastic nonlinear systems. As a result, Yin et al. firstly established the concept of finitetime stability in [30] and then succeeded in using the proved Lyapunov theorem to stabilize stochastic nonlinear systems in [31]- [32]. In recent years, on the basis of finite-time stability theory, the homogeneous domination approach, the adding a power integrator technique, switch control, backstepping and other design tools, many significant finite-time control results have been reported; e.g., high-order stochastic nonlinear systems [33], switched stochastic nonlinear systems [34], stochastic nonlinear systems with inverse dynamics [35], non-triangular stochastic nonlinear systems [36] and so on. However, there almost no finite-time control results on state constrained stochastic nonlinear systems except [37]. It is to be emphasized that the parametric uncertainties and input saturation are not considered in [37]. Obviously, further investigating the finite-time control for more general stochastic nonlinear systems with full-state constraints is an impending and challenging work. This is another motivation of this paper.

Motivated by the above discussions, this paper concerns the adaptive finite-time tracking control for stochastic nonlinear systems consisting of full-state constraints, input saturation and parametric uncertainties. The main contributions are highlighted as follows. (i). The considered system contains multiple uncertainties which is more general and can enlarge the practical application range. (ii). The concept of semi-globally finite-time stability in probability (SGFSP) in [36] is improved and a novel Lyapunov stability theorem is presented and proved. (iii). Two different methods are employed to handle the input saturation respectively. Under each method, the adaptive state-feedback controller can be obtained based on BLF and backstepping design. It is shown that the two proposed design schemes can guarantee the closed-loop system is SGFSP, the states are not violated and the system output can be driven to track a reference signal.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 begins with the preliminaries and problem formulation. In Section 3, an adaptive controller is designed and analyzed by using a function to approximate input saturation. In Section 4, an auxiliary system is introduced to achieve an adaptive controller. A simulation example is provided in Section 5, which is followed by Section 6 to conclude this paper.

div.head: A. Stochastic Stability Theory
div.p: Consider the normal stochastic nonlinear system
div.formula: dx = f (x)dt + g(x)dω, ∀x 0 ∈ R n , (1
div.p: where x ∈ R n is the system state; ω denotes an r-dimensional standard Wiener process defined on a complete probability space {Ω, F, P }, where Ω is a sample space, F is a σ-field and P is the probability measure; f (x): R n → R n and g: R n → R n×r are Borel measurable continuous functions. Definition 1 (see [6]): For a C 2 function V (x) ∈ R n , denote LV as the differential operator of V , then LV with respect to system (1) is given by LV
div.formula: (x) = ∂V (x) ∂x f (x) + 1 2 Tr{g T (x) ∂ 2 V (x) ∂x 2 g(x)}, where the term 1 2 Tr{g T ∂ 2 V ∂x 2 g} is called the Herssian term.
div.p: In the following, we present a new stability definition and the Lyapunov stability theorem.
Definition 2: The solution of system (1) is said to be semiglobally finite-time stability in probability (SGFSP), if (i). System (1) has a unique solution for any initial value x 0 ∈ R n ;

(ii). For every x 0 ∈ R n \ {Ω}, the stochastic setting time T (x 0 , ε) = inf{t : x(t; x 0 ) ∈ Ω} is finite almost surely; i.e., P {T (x 0 , ε) < ∞} = 1, where ε > 0 is a constant, Ω is a compact set and T (x 0 , ε) is the first time at which the set Ω is reached;
(iii). For ε > 0, the solution satisfies E(∥x(t; x 0 )∥) < ε, for all t ≥ T (x 0 , ε).

Remark 1: Note that [36] firstly gave the definition of SGFSP. However, the definition in [36] is incorrect. Firstly, it can't ensure the equilibrium x = 0 to be a solution of system (1) since f (x) and g(x) are only Borel measurable. According to [6], f (x) and g(x) should be locally bounded and locally Lipschitz continuous in x with f (0) = 0 and g(0) = 0 to admit a trivial zero solution. Secondly, even if system (1) has a trivial solution, the proof of Theorem 1 in [36] is still incorrect, we will illustrate this point later.

Remark 2: In light of condition (ii) in Definition 2, one obtains P {x(T (x 0 , ε); x 0 ) ∈ Ω} = 1. Then, by the uniqueness of solution in condition (i), x(t; x 0 ) ∈ Ω holds almost surely for t ≥ T (x 0 , ε); i.e., if x(t; x 0 ) enters the set Ω, then it will remain in Ω. In addition, if one defines Ω := {x|E(∥x(t; x 0 )∥) < ε}, then condition (ii) and condition (iii) can be combined into one condition.

Theorem 1: Consider system (1) and suppose f (x), g(x) are locally bounded and locally Lipschitz continuous in x with f (0) = 0 and g(0) = 0. If for any x 0 ∈ R n , there exist a positive definite, C 2 function V (x) ∈ R n , K ∞ class functions π 1 and π 2 , real numbers c > 0, ∆ > 0 and 0 < σ < 1 such that for all x ∈ R n and t ≥ 0, it holds
then, there exists a stochastic setting time T satisfying
with a constant 0 < δ < 1 such that the solution of system (1) is SGFSP.
Proof: Firstly, since V (x) ≥ 0, LV (x) ≤ ∆ holds for all x 0 ∈ R n . Then, it follows from the proof of Theorem 4.1 in [6] that there exists a unique strong solution of system (1).
From ( 2), there exists a constant 0 < δ < 1 such that
div.formula: LV (x) ≤ -cδV σ -c(1 -δ)V σ + ∆.(4)
div.p: Define
div.formula: Ω = {x|EV (x) ≤ ( ∆ (1-δ)c ) 1 σ }. In the sequel, two different cases are considered. Case I: x / ∈ Ω. Define τ m = inf{t ≥ 0 : ∥x(t)∥ > m} as the stopping time for ∀m ≥ 0. It is obvious that when m → ∞, τ m → ∞ holds. In this case, for ∀t ∈ [0, T ∧τ m ], we have EV (x) ≥ ( ∆ (1-δ)c ) 1 σ , which combines with (4) shows LV (x) ≤ -cδV σ ≤ 0.(5)
div.p: By applying similar proof procedure of Theorem 3.1 in [30], one can get
div.formula: P {T < ∞} = 1. Then, let V (x) = V 1-σ (x). Obviously, V (x) is a positive definite, C 2 function which satisfies E V (x) ≥ ( ∆ (1-δ)c ) 1-σ σ and (2) with π1 = π 1-σ 1 and π2 = π 1-σ 2
div.p: . By Itô's formula, one has
div.formula: E V (x(T ∧ τ m ; x 0 )) = E V (x 0 ) + E ∫ T ∧τm 0 L V (x(s; x 0 ))ds.(6)
div.p: Furthermore, in terms of ( 5), it is easy to obtain
div.formula: L V ≤ (1 -σ)V -σ LV + -σ(1 -σ) 2 •V -σ-1 Tr { g T ( ∂V ∂x ) T ∂V ∂x g } ≤ (1 -σ)V -σ LV ≤ -cδ(1 -σ),(7)
div.p: where g T ( ∂V ∂x ) T ∂V ∂x g is positive semi-definite. Hence, from ( 6)-( 7), one has
div.formula: E(T ∧ τ m ) ≤ E V (x 0 ) cδ(1 -σ) - E V (x(T ∧ τ m ; x 0 ) cδ(1 -σ) ,(8)
div.p: Letting m → ∞, then τ m → ∞ holds, which together with ( 8) and
gives (3). Moreover, letting
div.formula: T reach = 1 δc(1-σ) EV 1-σ (x 0 ) - 1 δc(1-σ) ( ∆ (1-δ)c ) 1-σ σ , one arrives at x(t; x 0 ) ∈ Ω for ∀T ≥ T reach .
div.p: Case II: x ∈ Ω. According to Case I, the trajectory of x(t; x 0 ) does not exceed the set Ω.
In conclusion, combining the above proof with Definition 2 results in Theorem 1 holding true.
Remark 3: This remark shows why the proof of Theorem 1 in [36] is incorrect. Note that only when
div.formula: ∫ T 0 ∂V ∂x g(x) cδV σ (x) dω is a martingale, E ∫ T 0 ∂V ∂x g(x) cδV σ (x) dω = 0 can hold. But in fact, ∫ T 0 ∂V ∂x g(x) cδV σ (x) dω is only a local martingale. Hence, directly using E ∫ T 0 ∂V ∂x g(x)
div.p: cδV σ (x) dω = 0 to prove Theorem 1 in [36] is not correct.

div.head: B. Problem Statement
div.p: This paper focuses on the stochastic nonlinear system
div.formula: dx i = h i x i+1 dt + θ T i f i (x i )dt + g i (x i )dω, dx n = h n u(v)dt + θ T n f n (x)dt + g n (x)dω, y = x 1 , i = 1, • • • , n -1,(9)
div.p: where x i ∈ R and y ∈ R are system measurable states and output constrained in the compact sets; i.e.,
div.formula: |x i | < k bi (i = 1, • • • , n) with k bi being known positive constants; x = (x 1 , • • • , x n ) T and xi = (x 1 , • • • , x i ) T ; h 1 , • • • , h n are known nonzero constants; ω is defined as those in (1); θ i ∈ R m is the unknown constant vector called as the parametric uncertainty; f i (x i ) ∈ R m and g i (x i ) ∈ R 1×r
div.p: represent the known smooth function vectors with f i (0) = 0 and g i (0) = 0. The input signal u(v) subjects to saturation nonlinearity defined by
div.formula: u(v) = sat(v) =    u M , v ≥ u M ; v, u m < v < u M ; u m , v ≤ u m . (10
div.p: where u M > 0 and u m < 0 are known constants. The control goal is to design an adaptive state-feedback controller such that system (9) is SGFSP, all states can't violate the predefined bounds and the related tracking performance can be obtained. For this aim, the following assumption is imposed on system (9).
Assumption 1 (see [17]): The tracking reference signal y r and its ith-order derivatives y
div.formula: (i) r (i = 1, • • • , n) satisfy max{y rm , y rM } ≤ A 0 < k b1 , -y rm ≤ y r ≤ y rM and |y (i) r | ≤ A i ,
div.p: where y rm , y rM , A 0 and A i are positive constants. We present some technical lemmas to end this section. Lemma 1 (see [3]): For any real numbers x, y, positive real constants m, n, b and continuous function a(•) ≥ 0, one has
div.formula: a(•)x m y n ≤ b|x| m+n + n m+n ( m+n m b) -m n a(•)
div.p: m+n n |y| m+n . Lemma 2 (see [4]):
div.formula: For z i ∈ R, i = 1, • • • , n and 0 < l < 1, it holds ( ∑ n i=1 |z i |) l ≤ ∑ n i=1 |z i | l ≤ n 1-l ( ∑ n i=1 |z i |) l .
div.p: Lemma 3 (see [24]): For any positive constant k c and any variable z ∈ R satisfies |z| < k c , one has log
div.formula: k 2p c k 2p c -z 2p ≤ z 2p k 2p c -z 2p
div.p: , where p is a positive integer.

div.head: III. ADAPTIVE CONTROLLER DESIGN BASED ON INPUT SATURATION APPROXIMATION
div.p: In this section, a smooth function g(v) is introduced to approximate the input saturation as
div.formula: g(v) = { u M tanh( v uM ), v ≥ 0; u m tanh( v um ), v < 0. . (11
div.p: Then, similar to [26]- [28], one can change system (9) into
div.formula: dx i = h i x i+1 dt + θ T i f i (x i )dt + g i (x i )dω, dx n = (h n g ′ v v + h n d(v))dt + θ T n f n (x)dt + g n (x)dω, y = x 1 , i = 1, • • • , n -1,(12)

div.head: IV. ADAPTIVE CONTROLLER DESIGN BASED ON AN AUXILIARY SYSTEM
div.p: As discussed in [29], introducing an auxiliary system to compensate input saturation is an effective way and can obtain the tracking performance by tuning design parameters in an explicit way. In this section, the following auxiliary system is introduced to handle input saturation
div.formula: dλ i = (h i λ i+1 -k i λ i )dt, dλ n = (h n ∆u -k n λ n )dt,(40
where i = 1, • • • , n -1; λ i (0) = 0; k 1 , • • • , k n are
div.p: positive design constants to be specified and ∆u = u(v) -v is the saturated input error. Then, define the state coordinate transformation as
div.formula: z 1 = x 1 -λ 1 -y r , z i = x i -α i -λ i , (41
div.p: where i = 2, • • • , n; y r still satisfies Assumption 1 and α 2 , • • • , α n are virtual control laws. In light of ( 9) and ( 40)-( 41), one has
div.formula: dz 1 = (h 1 (z 2 + α 2 ) + θ T s,1 f s,1 + k 1 λ 1 -ẏr )dt + g 1 dω, dz i = (h i (z i+1 + α i+1 ) + θ T s,i f s,i +k i λ i -⨿ i )dt + G i dω, i = 2, • • • , n -1, dz n = (h n v + θ T s,n f s,n + k n λ n -⨿ n )dt + G n dω,(42)

div.p: Then, by employing similar design procedure as in Section 3, constructing the BLF

div.p: where
div.formula: α n+1 = v; c i,1 = min{1, σ i λ min (Γ i )}; ∆ i,1 = ε i2 + (σ i λ min (Γ i ) + 1)(1 -l)l l 1-l + σi 2 ∥θ s,i ∥ 2 ; ϕ i1 = 3 4 (4ε i1 ) -1 3 h 4 3 i ; ϕ i2 = 1 2 (2ε i2 ) -1 ( 3k 4 ci +z 4 i 2 (1 + ( ∑ i-1 j=1 ∂αi ∂xj ) 2 ) ∑ i j=1 g 2 j ) 2 with ε i1 , ε i2 being positive constants and ϕ n1 = 0; Γ i = Γ T i > 0 is a design matrix and σ i > 0 is the design constant.
div.p: The following theorem provides the control performance in this section.

Theorem 3: For system (9) satisfying Assumption 1, when the adaptive controllers are chosen as (43)-( 45), one has: (i). There exists a finite time T * which satisfies (36) such that the closed-loop system consisting of ( 9), ( 40)-( 41) and ( 43)-( 45) is SGFSP; (ii). The tracking error z 1 is bounded by
(iii). System states are never violated; where 0 < δ < 1 is a
div.formula: constant; K = 8k 4 c1 (1-e -4( ∆ (1-δ)c ) 1 l ) > 0, k 0 = min{4 ki , i = 1, • • • , n} > 0, k1 = k 1 -1 4 > 0 and ki = k i -1 > 0 (i = 2, • • • , n) are design constants.
div.p: Proof: (i). Considering (46) and letting
div.formula: V = ∑ n i=1 V i , c = min{c i,1 , i = 1, • • • , n} and ∆ = ∑ n i=1 ∆ i,1
div.p: , similar to the proof of (i) in Theorem 2, one can calculate (i) holds.
(ii). Firstly, similar to (39), one can get
Then, in view of ( 41) and (48), one achieves

The following work is to find the bound of E(|λ 1 | 4 ).
For auxiliary system (40), constructing V λ = 1 4 ∑ n i=1 λ 4 i , which together with Definition 1 and Lemma 1 yields
where
By calculating (50) by e k0t and taking expectations on both sides, we have E(V λ ) ≤ E(V λ (0)e -k0t ) + 1 4k0 sup 0≤s≤t |∆u(s)| 4 , which together with V λ (0) = 0 gives
Hence, substituting (51) into (49), one can get (iii). Considering (i) and Definition 2, it is easy to obtain the boundedness of
div.formula: λ 1 , • • • , λ n . Assume |λ i | ≤ ξ i with ξ i being positive design constants, then |x 1 | = |z 1 + y r + λ 1 | < k c1 + A 0 + ξ 1 . Define k c1 = k b1 -A 0 -ξ 1 , then |x 1 | < k b1 .
div.p: Furthermore, in terms of (43)-(44), there must exist constants
div.formula: q i > 0 such that |α i | < q i , i = 2, • • • , n, which together with x i = z i + α i + λ i shows |x i | < k ci + q i + ξ i . Define k ci = k bi -q i -ξ i , then |x i | < k bi for i = 2, • • • , n.
div.p: That is to say the system states are not violated.

Remark 5: In [37], the finite-time results were directly obtained by assuming ∆ ≤ ∆ 0 cV l in (38) to get LV ≤ -(1 -∆ 0 )cV l and the finite time T * , where 0 < ∆ 0 < 1 is a design constant. However, it is hard to validate ∆ ≤ ∆ 0 cV l . In fact, if LV ≤ -(1 -∆ 0 )cV l holds, then V → 0 as t ≥ T * , thus ∆ ≤ ∆ 0 cV l ≤ 0. This is in contradiction with the fact that ∆ is a positive constant. This paper gives a novel Definition 2 and Theorem 1, based on which the finitetime results can be obtained more reasonably and rigorously. In particular, the input saturation is considered to extend the application range of this paper.

div.head: V. A SIMULATION EXAMPLE
div.p: To illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme, this section considers the following single-link Manipular.
Example 1: Consider the single-link robot arm consisting of a rigid link coupled through a gear train to a DC-motor. The dynamic equation is given by [38] as
div.formula: J q = -M gl 0 sin q -B q + u(v), (52
div.p: where q, q and q are the link angular displacement, velocity and acceleration, respectively; J is the moment of inertia; g is the acceleration of gravity; M and l 0 are the mass and length of the link; B q denotes the viscous damping with the damping coefficient B and u(v) is the saturated input torque. By using the same method as in [12] to introduce the stochastic white noise, treating B = B 0 + ∆B with B 0 = 0.5N • m • s as the uncertain variable and defining x 1 = q and x 2 = q, one can establish (52) as
div.formula: dx 1 = x 2 dt, dx 2 = 1 J u(v)dt + θ 2 f 2 (x 1 , x 2 )dt + g 2 dω, y = x 1 ,(53)
div.p: where θ 2 = l 0 , f 2 = -1 Jl0 M g sin x 1 -B0 J x 2 and g 2 = -σ J x 2 with σ 2 being the covariance of stochastic noise. For simulation, choose M = 1kg, l 0 = 1m, J = 0.5kg • m 2 , g = 9.8m/s 2 and σ = 0.1, which means f 2 = -19.6 sin x 1 -x 2 and g 2 = -0.2x 2 . The states are constrained by |x 1 | < 0.9 and |x 2 | < 3.5.
Then, by exactly following the design in Section 3 and Section 4, the adaptive controllers in similar forms of ( 33)-( 34) and ( 43)-(45) can be constructed in two cases.
Case 1: Using a smooth function to approximate u(v). Case 2: Using an auxiliary system to handle u(v).
In two cases,
and
T with ε 11 , ε 21 and ε 22 being design constants.

In simulation, choose y r = 0.3 cos(2t) -0.2, k c1 = 0.8 and k c2 = 2.5. The design constants are given by g vm = 0.5, From Fig. 1 and Fig. 2, one can see that in both cases the system states are not violated. From Fig. 1(b) and Fig. 2(b), it can be seen that the tracking error are bounded nearby the origin, which shows a satisfactory tracking performance. Particularly, the controller u in Fig. 1(b) appears multiple limit points while u in Fig. 2 only has one limit point at around 0.5s. This is because when encounters input saturation, the auxiliary system gives a more precise tuning of the tracking error and makes the control effort somewhat smaller.

0018-9286 (c) 2020 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission. See http://www.ieee.org/publications_standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSIONS
div.p: This note has investigated the adaptive tracking control for state-constrained stochastic nonlinear systems with unknown parameters and input saturation. The new definition of SGFSP and stochastic Lyapunov stability has been presented, which provides a basis of the controller design and analysis. Then, by using different tools to deal with input saturation, two adaptive controllers are obtained respectively, which ensures the closedloop system to achieve the property of SGFSP. In addition, the system states are not violated and the tracking error is bounded with expected bounds. An important problem under investigation is how to obtain the related results when system states are unmeasurable.

figure.figDesc: 4 and Γ 2 = [2, 0; 0, 2]. The initial values are chosen as x 1 (0) = 0.6, x 2 (0) = -0.5 and θs,2 (0) = 0. Fig. 1-Fig. 2 demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed schemes.
